intro: Quercus prinus var. michauxii, commonly known as the Michaux's chestnut oak, is a deciduous tree native to the eastern United States. It is characterized by its distinctive, elongated acorns and dark, glossy leaves that turn vibrant red in the fall. The tree typically grows to a height of 20–40 feet and has a broad, spreading crown. Its bark is gray and fissured, becoming more rugged with age. This variety is often found in moist, well-drained soils in mixed hardwood forests.
